date of birth: sex: m service: csu history of present illness: this is a 60 year old male transferred from in on for evaluation for coronary artery bypass grafting. he presented to the outside hospital on that day complaining of several hours of new-onset chest pain. he denied previous episodes of chest pain although had a stress test in which evoked some chest pain, increased heart rate which he did not have further testing for. cardiac catheterization at the outside hospital showed a distal left main stenosis of 70 percent, proximal lad of 50 percent, ostial circumflex of 50 percent, om1 of 40 percent, proximal rca of 50 percent and mid rca of 50 percent. past medical history: hypertension, diabetes type 2 for 17 years, peripheral vascular disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease and hyperlipidemia with a past surgical history of bilateral fem- grafts, iliac stenting, cholecystectomy and penile implant in . allergies: iv dye, penicillin, toradol and cipro. physical examination on presentation: height is 67 inches, weight 160 lb. vital signs - heart rate 62 in sinus rhythm. blood pressure is 140-160/50- general - not in acute distress. heent - normocephalic, atraumatic. pupils are equal, round and reactive to light. extraocular movements are intact, no jvd, positive carotid bruits bilaterally. cardiovascular - regular rate and rhythm with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. abdomen is soft, round and nontender and nondistended. extremities with positive bilateral fem- well-healed incision lines, no varicosities with good dp and pt pulses distally. labs on discharge: wbc is 7, hematocrit 6, platelets 277, glucose 146, bun 23, creatinine 2, sodium 142, potassium 7, chloride 104, bicarb concise summary of hospital course: the patient was admitted on as above. on day 1, he underwent some preop testing including carotid ultrasound showing only mild plaque on the right and left internal carotid arteries as well as bilateral lower extremity vein mapping

showing patent right greater saphenous vein, ankle to mid calf and patent bilateral lesser saphenous veins. on , he was taken to the operating room with doctor and underwent a cabg times three with a lima to the lad, saphenous vein graft to om and saphenous vein graft to the distal rca. total cardiopulmonary bypass time was 84 minutes and cross-clamp time of 64 minutes. he was transferred to the cardiac surgery recovery unit a-paced with a rate of 90 on neo, propofol and insulin drips. his initial operative course was uneventful. he was weaned and extubated successfully. on postoperative day 1, he was transferred to the inpatient floor for continued rehabilitation, physical therapy and discharge planning. he had a significant amount of immediate postoperative pain for which he was started on a morphine pca that significantly helped with his pain. was asked to see the patient by our team for uncontrolled diabetes. they recommended a change of his insulin regimen to lantus and humalog with follow-up plans with clinic including teaching. he was followed by physical therapy on postoperative day 4 and found to be safe for discharge home although he was kept for an extra 24 hours because of increased blood glucose levels and with better control, was discharged home on . condition on discharge: stable. discharge status: home with visiting nurses. discharge diagnoses: coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes type 2, hypertension, peripheral vascular disease. discharge medications: colace 100 mg po bid, aspirin 81 mg po daily, percocet 5/325 one to two tablets po q4h prn for pain, lipitor 10 mg po daily, lexapro 20 mg po daily, nicotine patch 14 mg per 24 hour patch transdermally daily for 7 days, then decreased to 7 mg patch transdermally daily for 14 days, potassium chloride 20 meq po daily for 7 days, lopressor 75 mg po bid, lasix 20 mg po daily

for 7 days, trazodone 50 mg po qhs, lantus insulin 22 units subcutaneously at bedtime and lispro insulin subcutaneously four times daily per sliding scale. follow up plans: the patient is to make an appointment with doctor in weeks, an appointment with doctor in 4 weeks, doctor in weeks and with the clinic for diabetes management. , md dictated by: medquist36 d: 14:18:37 t: 15:14:11 job#:

are noted. impression: no acute cardiopulmonary process. ekg : baseline artifact. sinus rhythm with ventricular premature beats. p-r interval prolongation. intraventricular conduction delay. consider inferior myocardial infarction. since the previous tracing of the rate has increased. ventricular premature beats are more frequent. q-t interval is shorter. ekg : no qt prolongation. brief hospital course: 67 year old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (ef <20%) s/p mi and icd with subsequent vt s/p ablation, h/o amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis presenting with icd discharges. . vt s/p icd discharge: patient had been ablated for vt in the past. however, his icd was interrogated by ep and showed 9 episodes of fast vt with cl 300-320 msec with similar morphology, some of which responded to atp while others required shock. he likely has scar mediated vt, likely from an inferior origin. there were no signs or symptoms suggestive of an acute ischemic trigger, and patient was continued on his home meds of asa, statin, beta blocker, and ace-i. tfts and electrolytes were within normal limits. the icd setting was changed from burst to a more agressive sequence, and his sotalol was increased from 120 mg to 160 mg ; amiodarone was discontinued as he had a h/o of amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis.

for the rest of his hospital course, pt remained asymptomatic with several short runs of nsvt on telemetry but no more significant arrhythmias. on discharge, pt was stable on sotalol with no need for amiodarone or ablation at this point; ekg with no qt prolongation. he will follow up with doctor . . amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis: endocrine was consulted and determined that patient's history was most consistent with type ii ait in light of his small nonnodular thyroid as well as absence of previous thyroid disease and antithyroid antibodies. his tfts were nl during this admission, and it was determined that it would be safe to restart the amiodarone if needed since the risk of ait recurrence is approximately 10%. at this time, the patient is not a candidate for thyroid ablation as he received a large iodine load from the initial amiodarone bolus. however, if amiodarone is restarted in the future, prophylactic thyroid ablation with radioiodine should be considered. pt will follow up with doctor . medications on admission: sotalol 120 mg aspirin 325 mg daily atorvastatin 40 mg daily metoprolol succinate 150 mg daily ramipril 10 mg daily amlodipine 5 mg daily esomeprazole 40 mg zantac 150 mg prn (averages 2x/week) discharge medications: omeprazole 20 mg capsule, delayed release(e.c.) sig: one (1) capsule, delayed release(e.c.) po bid (2 times a day). atorvastatin 40 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). aspirin 325 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). ramipril 5 mg capsule sig: two (2) capsule po daily (daily). amlodipine 5 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). toprol xl 50 mg tablet sustained release 24 hr sig: three (3) tablet sustained release 24 hr po once a day. sotalol 160 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po twice a day. disp:*60 tablet(s)* refills:*2* discharge disposition: home discharge diagnosis: primary: ventricular tachycardia . secondary: h/o amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis cad s/p mi

studies: cxr () findings: no previous images. endotracheal tube tip lies approximately 5 cm above the carina. nasogastric tube extends into the stomach. left ij catheter extends to about the junction of the left brachiocephalic vein and superior vena cava. there is patchy opacification at the right base consistent with the clinical impression of pneumonia. there may be similar, though much less prominent, changes on the left. mild prominence of the hilar regions is seen bilaterally of uncertain significance and etiology. brief hospital course: 92-y/o-man with past medical history of copd on home o2 who presented to with respiratory distress and pna, now s/p intubation for pna with bradycardia, transferred to for ep evaluation. # respiratory failure. mixed hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure given underling copd with possible excaberation and new rml pna. pt was initially treated with bipap but tired out with rising pco he was intubated on the morning of transfer (prior to transfer) with resulting improvement in respiratory acidosis. his pneumonia was covered broadly with vancomycin, cefepime, and doxycycline (he completed an 8-day course) and he was started on a prolonged steroid taper (methylprednisolone 60 mg x6 days switched over to prednisone on hospital day 7). he was extubated on but then re-intubated on (electively) for worsening hypercarbia. bronchoscopy performed immediately post-reintubation showed bronchomalacia, although this was not felt to be acute or likely contributing to his hypercarbia. steroids and antibiotics were continued, and his ventilation mechanics improved. he was again extubated on without complication. 24-hours post-extubation he was transferred to the general medicine floor. he can continue his home copd regimen after discharge as well as a 2 week prednisone taper. patient is recommended to have wear autoset cpap on 3l of supplemental o2 at nights # bradycardia. patient with sinus node dysfunction, pauses and some hypotension prior to transfer. be exacerbated by overall illness and fluoroquinolone. escape rhythm is narrow and likely from

the av-junction. ep was consulted immediately upon transfer and did not feel there was urgent indication for pacemaker. they recommended for dopamine drip titrated to maintain hr 50- as patient's pneumonia and copd were treated and improved, his sinus node dysfunction resolved and the dopamine was weaned off. ep felt that there was no need for pacemaker implantation during this admission. patient is being discharged with of hearts cardiac monitor to evaluate for irregular rhythms or further episodes of bradycardia # acute renal failure. this was likely prerenal azotemia and resolved with intravenous fluids. # hypothyroidism. patient was continued on his home regimen of levothyroxine. # diabetes type ii. patient was continued on his home regimen of glybride. # communication.
